column2: Gestational limit between 15 and 22 weeks LMP
column3:
Current gestational limit is 15 weeks LMP.

On April 9th, 2024, the State’s Supreme Court upheld the 1864 pre-Roe total ban, but it later delayed its enforcement through at least September 27, 2024. On May 2, 2024, the Governor signed a law repealing the pre-Roe ban, which will go into effect on September 13, 2024 (90 days after June 15, the day the legislative session adjourned). This means the pre-Roe ban will not go into effect before its repeal doe.

On November 5, 2024, voters passed a state constitutional amendment which will amend the state constitution to protect abortion up until viability.

column2: Gestational limit between 6 and 12 weeks LMP
column3:
The state's 6-week LMP ban is in effect as of May 1, 2024.
On April 1, 2024, the State Supreme Court ruled that the state constitution does not protect the right to abortion, and that the State's then 15-week ban was constitutional. The State's 6-week LMP ban, which had been signed by the Governor on 4/13/2023, contained language stating that it would only go into effect after 30 days after the State Supreme Court ruled on the constitutionality of the 15-week ban.
On November 5, 2024, Floridians voted on a ballot measure that would have amended the state constitution to protect abortion up until viability. While the measure got over 50% of votes, it failed to meet the state requirement of 60%

column2: Gestational limit between 6 and 12 weeks LMP
column3:

On October 7, the State Supreme Court reinstated the 6 week LMP ban that had been blocked by the Superior Court of Fulton County on September 30, 2024 while litigation is ongoing.

On November 5, 2024, Nebraskans voted on two citizen-initiated constitutional measures. A measure that would've amend the state constitution to recognize a fundamental right to abortion up to viability failed. The measure that will amend the constitution to ban abortion in the second and third trimesters passed.

The state's 6-week LMP ban is back in effect as of August 23, 2023. On 5/26/23 a judge had granted a stay blocking the enforcement of the State's 6-week LMP ban. This order was reversed on 8/23/23.
In January 2023, in a 3-2 ruling the South Carolina Supreme Court struck down the state's previous 6-week LMP ban as unconstitutional. In February 2023, the justice who wrote that ruling retired and was replaced by a new justice.

After the SCOTUS decision in Dobbs, the Wisconsin Attorney General challenged the state's pre-Roe ban, arguing it was not enforceable. In July 2023, a judge ruled that the 1849 law was not an abortion ban. The Attorney General had also previously stated that he would offer clemency to anyone prosecuted under the 1849 law.

Planned Parenthood has announced it will start providing abortions in the state starting September 18, 2023.
